page.text: 3.6 Sustainability - Vehicle Emissions, Noise, and Fuel Consumption ................................... 22
This report summarizes VHB’s findings regarding the most efficient final
configuration for the North Pleasant Street/Governors Drive/Eastman Lane
intersection. The following two improvement options were considered as the most
feasible options to address the current congestion at the intersection and balance
mobility for vehicles, pedestrians, and bicyclists:
Option 1 - Enhanced Signal Control – An enhanced signalized intersection
consisting of an additional southbound right-turn lane on North Pleasant Street
and an additional eastbound left-turn lane on Governors Drive. The enhanced
signal would include vehicle detection on all approaches using stop-line loops
embedded in the pavement that can detect gaps and shorten or lengthen green
times as needed to adapt to traffic demands. Pedestrian push buttons would be
Option 2 - Roundabout – A one-lane roundabout, or circular intersection, where
all approaches yield to the counterclockwise circulating traffic within the
roundabout. A roundabout is not the same premise as a large diameter, high
speed rotary. Rather, traffic yields upon entering the roundabout and circulates
at a posted speed of 20 miles per hour.
This report presents baseline conditions to demonstrate the need for improvements,
and presents a side-by-side comparison of both options with regard to traffic
operations, safety, pedestrian/bicycle accommodations, truck maneuverability, right-
of-way, vehicle emissions and fuel consumption, and costs. The following
Traffic Operations: Both Option 1 and Option 2 demonstrate marked
improvements over the existing signal with respect to queues. There is very little
difference when comparing Option 1 with Option 2, both yield similar queue
lengths. The roundabout under Option 2 yields lower vehicle delays than Option
Safety: Based on before and after studies completed by the Federal Highway
Administration and the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety, the roundabout
under Option 2 is expected to result in safer conditions for vehicles, pedestrians,
and bicyclists when compared to the upgraded signal under Option 1. This is
due primarily to several safety-related features of the roundabout, including:
1. Slower vehicle speeds that are similar to a bicyclist speed (20 miles per hour);
2. Drivers, pedestrians, and bicyclists pay more attention to the environment at
roundabouts; there is no false sense of right-of-way, no yellow-light
acceleration, or no red-light running with a roundabout;
3. Gaps in the traffic stream are easier to gauge and determine due to the
slower speeds and the fact that vehicles are only approaching from one
4. The crossing distances are shorter with splitter islands serving as a refuge
area; pedestrians are also more aware of the environment at a roundabout
Pedestrians and Bicyclists: The roundabout under Option 2 will yield more
efficient crossings with less conflict points for pedestrians and bicyclists when
compared to the upgraded signal under Option 1. The crossing distances are
actually longer under the signal compared to the roundabout. The majority of
pedestrians at the existing signal were observed crossing without using the push-
button, or without waiting for the exclusive crossing phase after pushing the
Tractor-trailers/Fire Trucks/PVTA Bus Maneuverability: Both Option 1 and
Option 2 accommodate semi-tractor trailers, fire trucks, and PVTA buses. The
roundabout under Option 2 includes a mountable truck apron within the layout
Right-of-way: Based on preliminary designs, there is no difference between
Option 1 and Option 2 with regard to right-of-way primarily because the
upgraded signal requires additional turning lanes. There is available right-of-

text.b: Sustainability - Greenhouse Gas Emissions, Noise, and Fuel Consumption:

page.text: Because the vehicle delays are reduced and the frequency of stop-and-start cycles
are reduced, Option 2 (roundabout) would yield significantly lower vehicle
emissions (Carbon Monoxide, Nitrous Oxide, Carbon Dioxide, Hydrocarbons),
noise, and fuel consumption when compared to Option 1.
Costs: The construction costs of Option 1 and Option 2 are similar. However, the
regular maintenance costs of the roundabout under Option 2 are lower than
Option 1 and the service life of the roundabout exceeds that of most signal
equipment. Thus, over the long term, Option 2 would be preferred from a
maintenance cost perspective over Option 1. The roundabout does require
special considerations and maintenance crew training and education for plowing
and drainage to ensure that the central island is not used to store plowed snow.

text.b: Based on this multimodal evaluation of vehicles, trucks, pedestrians, and
bicyclists, the one-lane roundabout (Option 2) is a more efficient, sustainable, and

page.text: cost effective option when compared to an enhanced traffic signal (Option 1). In
addition, the roundabout has the added benefit of creating a gateway entrance into
the campus from North Amherst which has the added benefit of slowing vehicle
Vanasse Hangen Brustlin, Inc. (VHB) has been retained by University of
Massachusetts (UMASS) Facilities and Campus Planning Department to recommend
enhancements and prepare concept plans for roadway and traffic improvements at
the intersection of North Pleasant Street/Governors Drive/Eastman Lane in
Amherst, MA. North Pleasant Street bisects the UMASS campus and the intersection
of North Pleasant Street/Governors Drive/Eastman Lane is the northern gateway to
The intersection is currently under a temporary signalized configuration while a
steam tunnel is constructed diagonally across the roadway. Given the opportunity
presented by the construction activity and the need to restore the intersection
configuration upon construction completion, UMASS retained VHB to explore the
most efficient configuration for the intersection once the construction is complete.
The North Pleasant Street corridor and the intersection fall under the jurisdiction of
the Town of Amherst. From the November 2009 zoning map for the Town of
), the land surrounding the intersection is
zoned Educational (ED) except for an area of the northwest quadrant of the
intersection in the vicinity of Farview Way which is zoned Neighborhood – Residence
(R-N). The intersection currently experiences long delays and queues in the morning
along North Pleasant Street southbound (toward the campus) and in the evening
along Governors Drive eastbound (leaving the campus toward North Amherst).
This Functional Design Report (FDR) includes a summary of traffic volumes,
roadway geometry, intersection analyses, conceptual designs, and costs. Findings
are provided based on the analysis. Recommendations for roadway and traffic
control improvements are defined in this FDR.
This report documents and quantifies the issues and deficiencies at the intersection of
North Pleasant Street/Governors Drive/Eastman Lane. The options explored for
enhanced roadway/traffic control are presented and compared in this report. This
report has been prepared to evaluate the following design conditions:
2009 Existing Traffic Volumes with Existing Geometry,
2009 Existing Traffic Volumes with Proposed Geometry (Option 1 and 2),
2019 Projected Traffic Volumes with Existing Geometry, and
2019 Projected Traffic Volumes with Proposed Geometry (Option 1 and 2).
The term “Geometry” represents all traffic control measures including physical
roadway geometry and traffic signals. A 10-year forecast to the year 2019 is used to
ensure the continued effectiveness of the improvements over the long term. For
planning purposes, a conservative 1 percent annual growth rate was applied to the
2009 baseline condition to arrive at a 2019 forecast.
This report and the analyses contained herein were prepared using methods and
procedures that are consistent with and based on the following state and federal
MassDOT Project Development and Design Guide;
American Association of State Highway Transportation Officials (AASHTO);
The Transportation Research Board Highway Capacity Manual (HCM); and
This chapter presents the existing conditions assessment and the methods used to
conduct the assessment. The purpose of this assessment is to help determine the need
for enhancements at the intersection of North Pleasant Street/Governors
Drive/Eastman Lane and set the framework and foundation for evaluating
Passenger vehicle, truck, pedestrian, and bicycle volumes were collected in both
March and May 2009 during periods when school was in regular session and
weather was amenable to walking and bicycling. The traffic data included daily
counts on North Pleasant Street, Governors Drive, and Eastman Lane, along with
peak hour intersection turning movement counts. The daily count data provides
insight into when peak periods occur and the intensity of traffic occurring during the
peak period while the peak hour counts are used for traffic operations analyses and
Daily automatic traffic recorder (ATR) data were collected for a typical weekday to
demonstrate hourly fluctuations. ATRs consist of pressurized tubes placed across the
road surface that count vehicles automatically as they pass over the tube. Figure 1
depicts the ATR data showing the hour-by-hour traffic fluctuations for all traffic
entering the North Pleasant Street and Governors Drive/Eastman Lane intersection.
Table 1 summarizes the daily traffic volumes.

text.b: FIGURE 1 – NORTH PLEASANT STREET AT GOVERNORS DRIVE/EASTMAN LANE -

c percent of daily traffic that occurs during the peak period

1. N. Pleasant St. NB (south of Governors Drive)
2. N. Pleasant St. SB (north of Governors Drive)
As Figure 1 indicates, the North Pleasant Street/Governors Drive/Eastman Lane
intersection is busiest in the evening peak hour when it processes approximately
1,400 vehicles per hour (vph). By comparison, in the morning peak hour the
intersection processes approximately 830 vph- 41 percent less than the evening peak
hour. The majority of the morning peak hour traffic entering the intersection is on
one approach - North Pleasant Street southbound (toward campus). In the evening
peak hour, all approaches are active (North Pleasant Street, Governors Drive, and
The ATR data summarized in Table 1 indicate the following:
North Pleasant Street carries approximately 10,200 vehicles per day (vpd) north
of the Governors Drive/Eastman Lane intersection and 7,500 vpd south of the
intersection. Peak hour volumes on North Pleasant Street vary from 5.2 to 8.1
percent of daily traffic. During the morning, the predominant traffic flow on
North Pleasant Street is southbound. During the evening, traffic is balanced in
Governors Drive carries 8,700 vehicles daily. Traffic on Governors Drive is
heavier in the westbound direction in the morning (away from North Pleasant
Street) and in the eastbound direction in the evening peak hour (toward North
Eastman Lane carries 6,300 vehicles daily. Mirroring traffic patterns on
Governors Drive, traffic on Eastman Lane is heavier in the eastbound direction in
the morning (away from North Pleasant Street) and in the westbound direction
in the evening (toward North Pleasant Street).
In addition to the ATR counts, manual turning movement counts (TMCs) were
conducted in March 2009 from 7:00 AM to 9:00 AM for the weekday morning peak
period and from 4:00 PM to 6:00 PM for the weekday evening peak period. These
TMC data are used as the primary inputs into the traffic operations analysis and
modeling. Figure 2 shows the resulting morning and afternoon peak hour traffic
volumes for existing conditions and forecasted 2019 conditions.
In May 2009, field surveys of pedestrian and bicycle activity were completed. These
surveys were completed to better understand the origin and destination travel
patterns of pedestrians and bicyclists to help inform the development of
improvement options regarding pedestrian and bicycle modes. Observations were
taken during the morning and afternoon peak periods, 7:00 to 9:00 AM and 4:00 to
6:00 PM. The traffic model used to evaluate the carrying capacity of the intersection
was calibrated with these pedestrian and bicycle activity levels.
Morning Peak Period. A total of 283 pedestrians and 31 bicyclists were observed
during the morning peak period, between 7:00 and 9:00 AM. During the
morning, the majority of the pedestrian and bicycle flows travelled southbound
on North Pleasant Street and westbound on Governors Drive.
Afternoon Peak Period. A total of 487 pedestrians and 83 bicyclists were
observed during the afternoon peak period, between 4:00 and 6:00 PM. The
afternoon peak period was busier than the morning peak period. During the
afternoon, the flow of pedestrians and bicycles were spread out almost evenly in
Pedestrian flows. By far the heaviest pedestrian directional flow observed was in
the vicinity of the northeast corner of the Hamlin House dormitories – where
pedestrians traveled between North Pleasant Street and Eastman Lane. This
movement does not require crossing the intersection.
Bicycle flows. The heaviest bicycle directional flow observed was 12 bicycles in
the morning and 25 bicycles in the afternoon traveling along North Pleasant
Street. During the morning, these 12 bicycles were travelling southbound on
North Pleasant Street (toward campus), while in the afternoon the 25 bicycles
observed were travelling northbound on North Pleasant Street (toward North
Amherst). Bicyclists used both the road and the sidewalks as travel ways,
depending on convenience. Approximately half of the bicyclists used the road
and half traveled on the sidewalks.
Diagonal crossing. Most of the pedestrians who parked their vehicles at the
Totman Gym lot were heading towards the back of the Lederle Graduate
Research Center (GRC). Most of these pedestrians crossed the intersection
The appendix to the report contains a detailed desire line analysis of pedestrian flows
showing the primary routes, secondary routes, and minor routes.
A safety assessment was conducted to help determine if safety concerns exist for
vehicles, pedestrians, or bicyclists. For this assessment, MassDOT intersection crash
data and rates were obtained from 2004 to 2007, the most recent three years of data
available. Crash rates were calculated based on the number of crashes relative to the
volume of traffic traveling through the intersection on a daily basis. Rates that
exceed MassDOT’s average district-wide rate could indicate safety or geometric
issues that warrant further examination. While the intersection is not under the
jurisdiction of MassDOT, safety analyses typically refer to statewide procedures to
help determine if the crash occurrence is excessive when compared to the traffic
A summary of the vehicle crash history at the intersection of North Pleasant Street at
Governors Drive/Eastman Lane is presented in Table 2. The following are the key
findings from the crash data review:
Frequency - There were a total of 11 crashes at the intersection of North Pleasant
Street and Governors Drive/Eastman Lane from 2005 to 2007. When compared
to the volume of traffic passing through the intersection, the 11 crashes result in a
crash rate of 0.60 crashes per million entering vehicle, which is below the
MassDOT average rate of 0.83, suggesting that the number of crashes is not
excessive when compared to the traffic demands served. None of the crashes
Crash Type - The most frequent crash type was rear-end collisions (5 crashes, 46
percent), followed by angle collisions (2 crashes, 18 percent), and sideswipes (2
crashes, 18 percent). Traffic signals by nature can result in increased rear-end
collisions compared to conditions without a traffic signal because they introduce
traffic flow interruptions on the main street for the benefit of the side street.
Severity - There were no fatal crashes at the intersection. The majority of the
crashes (7 crashes, 64 percent) involved property damage only. Injury crashes
accounted for 2 crashes (18 percent) over the three year period.
Time of Day – All of the crashes occurred during weekday off-peak conditions (7
crashes, 64 percent) or during the weekend (4 crashes, 36 percent). There were no
crashes during the morning or afternoon peak periods.
Pavement Conditions – Weather did not appear to influence the crashes since
the majority of crashes occurred during dry pavement conditions (9 crashes, 82
Weekday AM Peak, 7:00 AM to 9:00 AM
Weekday PM Peak, 4:00 PM to 6:00 PM
Source: VHB using MassDOT 2005-2007 Crash Data.
Crashes per million entering vehicles. MassDOT District 2 rate as posted, http://www.mhd.state.ma.us.
Understanding the relationship between the supply and demand is a fundamental
consideration in evaluating how well transportation infrastructure fulfills its
objective to safely and efficiently accommodate the traveling public. This section
presents the details of the traffic operations assessment for the study intersection.
The evaluation procedures and criteria used to analyze the study intersection are
based on the Highway Capacity Manual
Level of service (LOS) is a qualitative measure used to describe operational
conditions. Level of service incorporates factors such as speed, travel time, freedom
to maneuver, and traffic interruptions. Similar to a report card, level of service is
designated by levels A through F, with LOS A representing the best operating
conditions and LOS F the worst. The Highway Capacity Manual (HCM) does not
present a recommended level of service for design purposes. However, LOS E or
LOS F are generally considered unacceptable conditions leading to excessive delays
or queues which warrant an improvement.
Table 3 compares signal operations under existing conditions and 2019 conditions
under a “do nothing” scenario, where no intersection upgrades occur and the
intersection is restored to its exact condition before the construction activity started.

text.b: 2009 VOLUMES ON EXISTING GEOMETRY (before construction activity):
2019 VOLUMES ON EXISTING GEOMETRY (before construction activity):

Notes: NB = Northbound; SB = Southbound; EB = Eastbound; WB = Westbound; L = Left-turn; T = Through movement; R = Right-turn
Delay – Control delay per vehicle, expressed in seconds.
LOS – Level-of-Service. LOS A indicates free flow conditions with minimal delays. LOS E and F indicate congested conditions.
Q – 95th percentile queue length estimate, in feet (assume 25 feet per vehicle to convert queue length from feet to number of vehicles); shaded cells
denote queues that do not clear in one signal cycle.
During the morning peak hour, the busiest approach is North Pleasant Street
southbound. Southbound queues reach 390 feet, the equivalent of 16 vehicles. Under
Highway Capacity Manual 2000; Transportation Research Board, Washington, D.C., 2000
2019 conditions, these queues extend to 461 feet (18 vehicles). These queues are
excessive and do not clear within the signal cycle.
During the afternoon peak hour, Governors Drive is the busiest approach with
queues reaching 465 feet (approximately 19 vehicles). Under 2019 conditions, these
queues extend to 540 feet (22 vehicles). These queues are excessive and do not clear
There is notable bus and truck activity through the intersection and headed along
North Pleasant Street to Governors Drive. Before the construction activity
commenced, the southbound right turn movement (North Pleasant Street
southbound to Governors Drive) was very difficult for trucks and buses due to the
tight radius at this corner of the intersection. If there was a vehicle on Governors
Drive waiting at the signal, the buses/trucks will encroach over the curb.
Fortunately, the sidewalk was set back behind a tree so this curb encroachment is not
creating a pedestrian safety issue. The current configuration of the intersection has
addressed the difficult southbound right-turn through the provision of a larger
The following key observations and conclusions were made in this chapter:
Pedestrians and Bicyclists. There are notable pedestrian and bicyclist demands
at the intersection. A total of 283 pedestrians and 31 bicyclists were observed
during the morning peak period, between 7:00 and 9:00 AM. During the
morning, the majority of the pedestrian and bicycle flows travelled southbound
on North Pleasant Street and westbound on Governors Drive. The afternoon
peak period was busier than the morning peak period. A total of 487 pedestrians
and 83 bicyclists were observed during the afternoon peak period, between 4:00
and 6:00 PM. During the afternoon, the flow of pedestrians and bicycles were
spread out almost evenly in all directions through the intersection. Bicyclists
used both the road and the sidewalks as travel ways, depending on convenience.
Approximately half of the bicyclists used the road and half traveled on the
Crashes. There were no fatal crashes at the intersection and the occurrence of
crashes is below the MassDOT District average. None of the crashes involved
Excessive queues and delays. During the morning peak hour, southbound
queues on North Pleasant Street reach 390 feet, the equivalent of 16 vehicles.
Under 2019 conditions, these queues are expected to extend to 461 feet (18
vehicles). During the afternoon peak hour, Governors Drive is the busiest
approach with queues reaching 465 feet (approximately 19 vehicles). Under 2019
conditions, these queues are expected extend to 540 feet (22 vehicles). These
queues are excessive and do not clear within the signal cycle.
Finally, the intersection of North Pleasant Street/Governors Drive/Eastman Lane is
the northern gateway to the campus. However, the current intersection configuration
does not convey a gateway transition into a campus setting where the presence of
pedestrians and bicyclists crossing North Pleasant Street is significantly increased.
Given the opportunity presented by the construction activity and the operational
issues as described in Chapter 2, UMASS wanted to explore the most efficient final
configuration for the North Pleasant Street/Governors Drive/Eastman Lane
intersection. After reviewing the baseline condition, two improvement options
surfaced as the most feasible options that most efficiently address the excessive
queuing that occurs. Roadway and traffic control improvements have progressed to
a conceptual design stage for the following two options:
Option 1 - Enhanced Signal Control – An enhanced signalized intersection
consisting of an additional southbound right-turn lane on North Pleasant Street
and an additional eastbound left-turn lane on Governors Drive. The enhanced
signal would include vehicle detection on all approaches using stop-line loops
embedded in the pavement that can detect gaps and shorten or lengthen green
times as needed to adapt to traffic demands. Pedestrian push buttons would be
Option 2 - Roundabout – A one-lane roundabout, or circular intersection, where
all approaches yield to the counterclockwise circulating traffic within the
roundabout. This is not the same premise as a large diameter, high speed rotary.
Rather, traffic yields upon entering the roundabout and circulates at a posted
speed of 20 miles per hour. Bicycles are provided the option of traveling as a
vehicle or as a pedestrian on the sidewalk.
This chapter presents a side-by-side comparison of both options with regard to traffic
operations, safety, pedestrian/bicycle accommodations, truck maneuverability, right-
of-way, vehicle emissions and fuel consumption, and costs.
Tables 4 and 5 compare an upgraded signal to a one-lane roundabout. Signal
operations were evaluated using SYNCHRO 7 software and the 1-lane roundabout
was evaluated using SIDRA 3.2 software. Both SYNCHRO and SIDRA are based on
industry standard procedures from the 2000 Highway Capacity Manual. The
roundabout was also modeled using the VISSIM software.

In addition to estimating the traffic operations of the roundabout using SIDRA and
VISSIM, capacity estimates of roundabouts from the Federal Highway
Administration (FHWA) were referenced along with the observed traffic demands to
ensure that a roundabout is an appropriate traffic control measure given the entering
volumes and the circulating volumes. Based on FHWA guidance and research of
roundabouts in the United States, the roundabout would operate at below 65 percent
of capacity, as shown in the chart below.
Both the enhanced traffic signal and the roundabout are expected to greatly reduce
the excessive queues that occur under the existing intersection configuration.
Comparing the upgraded traffic signal to the roundabout indicates that the
roundabout and enhanced traffic signal are essentially identical in terms of queue
mitigation, as shown in the chart below.

text.b: Conclusion: Both Option 1 and Option 2 demonstrate marked improvements over
the existing signal with respect to queues. There is very little difference when
comparing Option 1 with Option 2, both yield similar queue lengths. Option 2

page.text: The number of conflict points at the intersection is greatly reduced with a
roundabout when compared to a traffic signal. The fewer conflict points has been
shown to result in fewer crashes for vehicles, pedestrians, and bicyclists. Conflict
Vehicle conflict points are reduced by 75 percent from 32 (4-way signal) to 8
Pedestrian conflict points are reduced by 50 percent from 16 (4-way signal) to 8
Bicycle conflict points for each approach are reduced by 50 percent from 24 (4-
Comparing a 4-way signalized intersection to a roundabout, the reduction in speeds
and conflict points translates into fewer crashes overall and lower rates of severity.
The FHWA findings from research and before-and-after observations across the
United States have shown a 51 percent reduction in crashes and a 73 percent
reduction in injury-related crashes when comparing a 4-way signalized intersection
to a roundabout. Similar studies by the Maryland DOT show a 68 percent reduction
in total crashes and 86 percent reduction in injury crashes.
The Insurance Institute for Highway Safety revealed the following crash reduction
trends associated with roundabouts compared to signalized intersections:
30 to 40 percent reduction in pedestrian crashes;
10 percent reduction in bicycle crashes; and
90 percent reduction in incapacitating injuries and fatal crashes.

text.b: Conclusion: Based on national studies and before-and-after comparisons, the
roundabout under Option 2 is expected to result in safer conditions for vehicles,
pedestrians, and bicyclists when compared to the upgraded signal under Option 1.
This is the direct result of the fewer conflict points and slower speeds associated

page.text: While the designs for Option 1 and 2 are still evolving, both will be ADA/AAB
compliant and have improved accommodations for pedestrians and bicyclists
compared to the existing signal. The enhanced signal under Option 1 will include
push buttons and pole mounted pedestrian signals at all four crosswalks. The
roundabout under Option 2 will include sidewalks around the outer edge of the
roundabout with median islands at each approach, spaced approximately one vehicle
length back from the roundabout entry point. As currently envisioned, a grass buffer
will be provided to separate the sidewalk from the travelway.
From the pedestrian survey mentioned in Chapter 2, by far the heaviest pedestrian
directional flow observed was in the vicinity of the northeast corner of the Hamlin
House dormitories – where pedestrians traveled between North Pleasant Street and
Eastman Lane. This movement does not require crossing the intersection.
For bicyclists, the roundabout would be designed to accommodate bicyclists within
the roundabout (share the road) or via sidewalk ramps to access the
sidewalk/crosswalks if preferred (wider sidewalks would be provided). As noted in
Chapter 2, approximately half of the bicyclists traveling through the intersection
used the road and half traveled on the sidewalks, and this behavior is expected to
continue with the roundabout under Option 2.
National statistics indicate that for single-lane roundabouts, the number of
pedestrian crashes is about 3 to 4 times less than that of a signalized intersection.
Moreover, the severity of pedestrian crashes is lower for roundabouts than for other
forms of traffic control. Similarly, bicycle crashes are reduced by 10 percent. This is
primarily because roundabouts eliminate left-turns, right-turns, and associated
conflicts common at conventional intersections. Other key several safety-related
1. Slower vehicle speeds that are similar to a bicyclist speed (20 miles per hour);
2. Drivers and pedestrians and bicyclists pay more attention to the
environment at roundabouts; there is no false sense of right-of-way;
3. Gaps in the traffic stream are easier to gauge and determine due to the
slower speeds and the fact that vehicles are only approaching from one
4. The crossing distances are shorter with splitter islands serving as a refuge
area and also making the pedestrian more aware of his/her environment

text.b: Conclusion: Based on before-and-after evaluations of signals and roundabouts, the
roundabout under Option 2 is expected to yield more efficient crossings with less
conflict points for pedestrians and bicyclists when compared to the upgraded
signal under Option 1. Vehicle speeds are slower, which has shown to yield fewer
crashes and reduced severity of crashes.

page.text: A key problem with the intersection before the construction activity was the
inadequate turning radius for buses and trucks. The southbound right turn
movement (North Pleasant Street southbound to Governors Drive) was very difficult
for trucks and buses due to the tight radius at this corner of the intersection. If there
was a vehicle on Governors Drive waiting at the signal, the buses/trucks will
encroach over the curb. The current condition of the intersection addresses this issue.
Option 1 and 2 were each designed to accommodate trucks and buses. In addition to
testing large semi-tractor trailers (WB-50 type), vehicle specifications were provided
by the Amherst Fire Department and Pioneer Valley Transit Authority (PVTA) and
these vehicle types were included in the design review. From the Amherst Fire
Department, an aerial platform truck was tested. Gillig Low Floor Buses (with bicycle
racks) were tested for the PVTA.

text.b: Option 2, with a mountable truck apron, under WB-50 vehicle tracking:
Conclusion: Both Option 1 and Option 2 equally accommodate semi-tractor
trailers, fire trucks, and PVTA buses.

page.text: The preliminary layout indicates that both a one-lane roundabout and upgraded
traffic signal could be accommodated within the existing travel way and current

text.b: Conclusion: Based on preliminary designs, there is no difference between Option
1 and Option 2 with regard to right-of-way. There is available right-of-way to

page.text: Reducing vehicle delays and greenhouse gas emissions will improve air quality by
reducing the amount of time vehicles are sitting idle at an intersection. Moreover,
fuel consumption is increased with added stopped delays. In addition, vehicles can
create significant noise pollution while idling and accelerating through an
The chart below compares the overall vehicle delays under the existing signal (do
nothing option), the upgraded signal (Option 1), and the roundabout (Option 2).
FHWA statistics suggests that given the daily traffic demands at the intersection,
there would be an annual delay reduction of approximately 4,000 vehicle-hours per
year with a roundabout over an upgraded signal.
The upgraded traffic signal yields a 45 percent reduction in delays compared to the
existing signal. Similarly, the roundabout yields a 50 percent reduction in delays
compared to the upgraded signal. From the perspective of improved air quality
reduced fuel consumption, the roundabout clearly outperforms the existing and
National statistics on roundabout performance confirm that roundabouts
significantly reduce greenhouse gas emissions and fuel consumption compared to
traffic signals. A 2004 study of roundabouts across the United States found that
roundabouts reduced Carbon Monoxide emissions by 32 percent, Nitrous Oxide
emissions by 34 percent, Carbon Dioxide emissions by 37 percent, Hydrocarbon
emissions by 42 percent, and overall fuel consumption by 30 percent.
A similar study in 2009 by the New York State DOT also found reductions in
greenhouse gas emissions after a detailed before-and-after air quality assessment,

text.b: Conclusion: Option 2 (Roundabout) would yield lower vehicle greenhouse gas
emissions (Carbon Monoxide, Nitrous Oxide, Carbon Dioxide, Hydrocarbons),
noise, and lower fuel consumption when compared to Option 1.

page.text: Conceptual cost estimates were prepared based on the concept plans for Option 1
and Option 2. These costs are based on MassDOT unit prices for materials and
include a 25 percent contingency to account for utility modifications, signage,
The conceptual construction cost estimate for Option 1, the upgraded traffic signal, is
$495,000. Option 2, the roundabout, has conceptual construction cost estimate of
While Option 1 and 2 have similar construction costs, long-term maintenance and
utility costs associated with Option 2 are notably lower than Option 1. A traffic signal
requires power and regular signal head and controller maintenance estimated at
approximately $5,000 per year. Moreover, the service life of a roundabout is
approximately 25 years compared to a 10 year service life of most signal equipment.

text.b: Conclusion: The construction costs of Option 1 and Option 2 are similar. However,
the regular maintenance costs of the roundabout under Option 2 are lower than
Option 1 and the service life of the roundabout exceeds that of most signal
equipment. Thus, over the long term, Option 2 would be preferred from a

page.text: Based on the multimodal evaluation of vehicles, trucks, pedestrians, and
bicyclists, the one-lane roundabout (Option 2) is a more efficient and cost

text.b: effective option when compared to an enhanced traffic signal (Option 1).

page.text: Under a roundabout, vehicle delays are reduced and emissions and fuel
consumption are reduced. The reduction in vehicle stop-and-start cycles will
yield noise reductions through the roundabout.
Based on national research, the roundabout would provide the added benefit of
improving safety for vehicles, pedestrians, and bicyclists compared to a traffic
signal. Moreover, the roundabout creates a gateway entrance into the campus
from North Amherst which is important since the character of North Pleasant
Street transitions to a slower, pedestrian-zone at the intersection. The
roundabout serves as an effective transition into this pedestrian-dominated zone
The next steps to consider are as follows:
Review the two options considered with UMASS officials and develop a
consistent approach and strategy moving forward, identifying either Option
1 or Option 2 as the preferred approach to bring forward to the Town of
Present recommendations to the Town of Amherst officials and residents for
review and comment since the intersection is under the jurisdiction of the
Town of Amherst. Using the concept plans, initiate the Town planning and
For the preferred option, initiate detailed engineering design which will be
used to further advance the planning and approval process as needed.
Develop construction phasing and maintenance of traffic plans. Update cost
Initiate public outreach and education campaign. This is critically important
if the recommended roundabout configuration is selected to dispel the
perception that a roundabout might function like a rotary.
